abstract.text: Asks Apple to attest to the validity of a generated cryptographic key.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: The identifier you received when generating a cryptographic key by
calling the
method.
A SHA256 hash of a unique, single-use data block that
embeds a challenge from your server. Should be at least 16 bytes in length.
A closure that the method calls upon completion with
the following parameters:
: A statement from Apple about the validity of the key
associated with
. Send this to your server for processing.
: A
instance that indicates the reason for
failure, or
on success.
You can call this method from synchronous code using a completion handler,
as shown on this page, or you can call it as an asynchronous method that has the
following declaration:

code: func attestKey(_ keyId: String, clientDataHash: Data) async throws -> Data

inlineContent.text: For information about concurrency and asynchronous code in Swift, see
This method asks Apple to attest to the validity of a key that you
previously generated with a call to the
method.
Provide the method with both the key identifier and a computed hash of a
data block that includes a one-time challenge from your server to prevent
replay attacks. For example, you can use CryptoKit to create a
hash of
challenge data:

code: import CryptoKit let hash = Data(SHA256.hash(data: challenge)) // A

inlineContent.text: The attest method calls its completion handler to return an attestation
object to you, which you must send to your server for verification. A
compromised version of your app could falsify the verification result, thus
circumventing App Attest.
If you successfully verify the attestation object on your server, as
described in
, then you can
associate the key identifier with the user on the device for future
reference. You’ll need the identifier to generate assertions with calls to
If your server fails to verify the attestation object, discard the key
identifier.
If the method’s completion handler returns the
error — typically due to network
connectivity issues — it means that the framework failed to reach the App
Attest service to complete the attestation. In this case, retry attestation
again using the same key and client data hash later to avoid unnecessarily
generating new keys. Retrying with the same inputs helps to preserve the
risk metric for a given device.

abstract.text: Reduce fraudulent use of your services by managing device state and asserting app
integrity.
A service that you use to validate the instance of your app running on a
device.
Asks Apple to attest to the validity of a generated cryptographic key.
Creates a block of data that demonstrates the legitimacy of an instance of
your app running on a device.
Creates a new cryptographic key for use with the App Attest service.
A type that indicates when DeviceCheck encounters an error.
An error that indicates a failed attempt to contact the App Attest service during an attestation.
Ensure that requests your server receives come from legitimate instances of your
app.
Test your implementation in a development environment and onboard users gradually.

doc://com.apple.DeviceCheck/documentatio.title: Preparing to use the app attest service

abstract.text: Verify that connections to your server come from legitimate instances of your app.

doc://com.apple.DeviceCheck/documentatio.title: Validating apps that connect to your server

abstract.text: An implementation of Secure Hashing Algorithm 2 (SHA-2) hashing with a 256-bit digest.
Learn how functions and methods that take a completion handler are converted to Swift asynchronous functions.
A byte buffer in memory.
A Unicode string value that is a collection of characters.
The return type of functions that don’t explicitly specify a return type, that is, an empty tuple `()`.
A type representing an error value that can be thrown.
